text: We use Notion as well. And before we just had an editorial calendar on shared excel in Google drive (but I did not like it). text: I’m creating an internal process + guide for producing case studies (for a SaaS company) — does anyone have good resources or advice that they can share?

elements.text: I’m creating an internal process + guide for producing case studies (for a SaaS company) — does anyone have good resources or advice that they can share?

text:
Hi SiNing! I use Trello and it works beautifully. I have different lists for different content by platform (blog, Medium, newsletter, social channels). There is a great Calendar view so I can see how everything lines up, and it also has a GCal version so I can see my content in my Google Calendar (along with everything else I have going on!)

I have a generic list in Trello for ideas that I haven't fleshed out yet. Once I decide what I'm going to do, I move it to one of the other lists. Trello also has the ability to add tasks to a card. I don't use this feature because my needs are very straightforward, but if you were planning a bigger piece of content you could use that to set to-dos along the way. I also have some automations running in the background so that a larger piece of content (like a blog post) gets repurposed as smaller content later (like Tweets).

Let me know if there's any other info I can provide that might be helpful!

text: We use asana -- we have templates for blog posts, webinars, etc and all the related subtasks (drafting, editing, uploading, etc). Parent tasks show up on a calendar by publication date. Ideas list lives in a google doc linked to the main blog project, so it's right there even though the ideas aren't technically in asana.

text: Any CRO experts in here? We’ve done a lot of work increasing web traffic but it’s made our conversion rate tank. I’m currently reading <https://conversion-rate-experts.com/book/|Making Websites Win> to get some strategies, but I’m hoping to source some advice from all you experts in here! :sparkles: :slightly_smiling_face: All advice welcome! Kind of new to CRO (usually focused on SEO, not what to do with that hard earned traffic :sweat_smile::upside_down_face:)

text:
Hey Ryan, I'm not an expert but I write for some CRO experts: <https://thegood.com/insights/>

They serve ecommerce stores, but some of their thinking may be helpful for you? Sharing in case it is.

attachments.text: The Good's Insights are in-depth weekly articles, white papers, webinars, and more designed to educate leading marketers on conversion optimization and A/B testing.
attachments.title: Insights Archive

elements.text: Hey Ryan, I'm not an expert but I write for some CRO experts:
They serve ecommerce stores, but some of their thinking may be helpful for you? Sharing in case it is.

text:
When you say your conversion rate tanked, do you mean across all of your articles and pages? Or just across some of the new ones?

If you want to get your conversation rate back up, start talking directly to customers (or the people that talk to customers) and throw search volume out of the window. I call it the "3S" strategy.

files.name: Growth Sprints Capabilities and Case Studies.png
files.title: Growth Sprints Capabilities and Case Studies.png

elements.text:
When you say your conversion rate tanked, do you mean across all of your articles and pages? Or just across some of the new ones?

If you want to get your conversation rate back up, start talking directly to customers (or the people that talk to customers) and throw search volume out of the window. I call it the "3S" strategy.

text: Also like <@UL4TUV38B> said, this is a great book on CRO <https://thegood.com/opting-in-to-optimization/>

attachments.fallback: The Good: Opting In To Optimization
attachments.text: Packed with evidence-based strategies, Opting In To Optimization will teach you how to convert more visitors into buyers through better shopping experiences.
attachments.title: Opting In To Optimization

elements.text: Also like
said, this is a great book on CRO

text: <@UUKNLHZ4H> :point_up:

From a technical standpoint, I checked out your most popular articles in Ahrefs and there's SO much we can do to think through more conversions. Shoutout to <@U029G4FSC1M> for writing one of the most popular ones!

Where I'd start:

• Move an optin closer to the top or add it to the TOC that follows you as you scroll.
• Analyze the TOC - does anybody click those social share links? Do we need them? Personally, I'd recommend removing them in favor of a button to get the download.
• Re-frame your optin - "Download our whitepaper" isn't compelling (at all) for how great it probably is. Lead with the value. More along the lines of "Want to [HUGE RESULT] with your mentorship program? Here's how..."

elements.text: From a technical standpoint, I checked out your most popular articles in Ahrefs and there's SO much we can do to think through more conversions. Shoutout to

for writing one of the most popular ones!

Where I'd start:
Move an optin closer to the top or add it to the TOC that follows you as you scroll.
Analyze the TOC - does anybody click those social share links? Do we need them? Personally, I'd recommend removing them in favor of a button to get the download.

Re-frame your optin - "Download our whitepaper" isn't compelling (at all) for how great it probably is. Lead with the value. More along the lines of "Want to [HUGE RESULT] with your mentorship program? Here's how..."

text:
Thanks for the shoutouts, folks! :heart:

Our public positioning is all around ecommerce, but we’ve worked with big software companies (Ex: Adobe, Xerox) and publications (Ex: The Economist, Telegraph). Anyone that sells products online is technically participating in ecommerce, right?

Anyways, our specialty is mostly around site structure and copy, with the aim of getting someone to make a purchase, start a free trial, or complete an onboarding sequence.

Happy to take a look if that is reflective of your challenges. If you’re talking more about getting your *content* to drive more customers your way, I certainly have some thoughts, but I wouldn’t consider myself an expert.

content
to drive more customers your way, I certainly have some thoughts, but I wouldn’t consider myself an expert.

text: Echoing the mentions of Trello! We use a Kanban style board with columns for: Incoming Topics, Approved Topics, Content In Progress, and Ready for Distribution. We use color coded labels to signify the persona, the channel (i.e. email, social media) and the format (video, etc.) and of course we can include due dates where they are applicable.

We use color coded labels to signify the persona, the channel (i.e. email, social media) and the format (video, etc.) and of course we can include due dates where they are applicable.
